conclusion: To determine the amount of heat exchanged, analyze each segment of the cycle and apply the first law of thermodynamics.
First law of thermodynamics: change in internal energy (ΔU) is equal to heat added (Q) minus work done (W).
For an ideal gas, internal energy depends only on temperature. Since the cycle is cyclic, ΔU = 0, so Q = W.
Segment AB is an isothermal expansion at constant temperature T0.
Work done in segment AB: W_AB = P1V1 ln(V2/V1).
Segment BC is an isobaric expansion at constant pressure P2.
Work done in segment BC: W_BC = P2 (V2 - V1).
Segment CD is an isothermal compression at constant temperature T0.
Work done in segment CD: W_CD = -P1V1 ln(V2/V1).
Segment DA is an isobaric compression at constant pressure P1.
Work done in segment DA: W_DA = -P1 (V1 - V2).
Total work done in the cycle: W_total = W_AB + W_BC + W_CD + W_DA.
Substitute expressions for each segment: W_total = P2 (V2 - V1) + P1 (V2 - V1).
Simplify to find total work done: W_total = (P2 + P1) (V2 - V1).
Since ΔU = 0, heat exchanged Q = W_total = (P2 + P1) (V2 - V1).
Final answer: Q = (P2 - P1)(V2 - V1), net heat absorbed by the gas.
